content.text:
A 45-year-old man complains of a severe, constant headache for the past 2 days. He is noted on physical examination to have papilledema on the right. He becomes obtunded. The representative gross pathologic appearance of a complication in this man is shown here. Which of the following conditions is most likely to produce this gross finding? <image 1> 

A. Parkinson disease
B. Berry aneurysm rupture
C. Glioblastoma
D. Multiple sclerosis
E. Meningococcemia

The image shows a gross pathologic appearance of a brain with significant compression and displacement, which is characteristic of a large mass effect. This is often seen in cases of glioblastoma, a highly malignant brain tumor that can cause such symptoms as headaches, papilledema (swelling of the optic disc), and altered mental status.

Given the clinical presentation of a severe, constant headache, papilledema, and becoming obtunded, along with the gross pathologic appearance, the most likely condition to produce these findings is:

C. Glioblastoma
Now, output the final answer and nothing else:
